case_vignette: An 8-year-old male presents with 1 week of itchy blisters on the ears. He just recently returned from spring break with his family. He denies using any particular products on the ears before the rash. He says that this has occurred yearly for the last several years, always around the same time. He denies proximal muscle weakness. He denies flaking in the scalp.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have itchy blisters on my ears that started about a week ago.
Great, thank you for letting me know! Can you tell me, are you a male or female? And approximately how old are you?
I am a male and I am 8 years old.

Excellent, thank you for confirming! Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you a few more questions to help me narrow down the possible causes of your itchy blisters on your ears.

Have you noticed any other symptoms, such as fever, fatigue, or difficulty hearing? And have you had any recent illnesses or infections?
No, I haven't had any fever, fatigue, difficulty hearing, or recent illnesses.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you a few more questions to help me determine the possible cause of your itchy blisters on your ears.

Have you noticed any changes in your skin recently, such as dryness, redness, or irritation? And have you used any new skincare products or cosmetics recently that could be causing the itchiness?
I haven't used any particular products on my ears before the rash and I haven't noticed any other skin changes.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you a few more questions to help me determine the possible cause of your itchy blisters on your ears.

Have you had any allergies or sensitivities in the past? And have you noticed any other symptoms, such as itching or redness, on any other parts of your body?
This has happened yearly for the last several years, always around the same time, but no other parts of my body are itchy or have redness.

Thank you for providing that information. Based on what you've told me, I would like to ask a few more questions to help narrow down the possible causes of your itchy blisters on your ears.

Have you noticed any patterns or triggers that seem to cause the itchiness to occur? For example, do you notice that the itchiness starts after exposure to certain environmental factors, such as cold weather or dry air?

Also, have you tried any over-the-counter treatments or remedies for the itchiness, and if so, what was the effect?
The itchy blisters seem to occur every year around spring break, but I haven't tried any treatments for it.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to make a diagnosis of contact dermatitis. Contact dermatitis is a common skin condition that occurs when the skin comes into contact with an allergen or irritant, leading to inflammation and itching.

It's possible that the itchy blisters on your ears are caused by a reaction to something you came into contact with during spring break, such as a new soap or shampoo, or even a plant or substance you touched while spending time outdoors.

I recommend avoiding any potential allergens or irritants and using a topical corticosteroid cream or ointment to help reduce the itching and inflammation. If the symptoms persist or worsen, you may need to see a dermatologist for further evaluation and treatment.

Is there anything else you would like to know or discuss?
Thank you, I will follow your recommendations and let you know if my symptoms persist or worsen.

You're welcome! I'm glad I could help. Please do keep me updated on your symptoms and if you have any concerns or if your symptoms persist or worsen, don't hesitate to reach out to me or consult with a dermatologist. They can provide you with further evaluation and treatment options.

Remember, it's important to take good care of your skin and to be aware of any changes or unusual symptoms, as early detection and treatment can help prevent more serious complications.

Thank you for sharing your symptoms with me, and please feel free to ask any other questions or concerns you may have.
